snippet: Two important southern primaries are leading Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich to battle each other as they try to show they can unite the party’s conservative base.
abstract: Rick Santorum's campaign and his allies begin prodding Newt Gingrich to abandon the primary race so that conservatives can unite behind Santorum against Mitt Romney; Gingrich rejects appeals, focusing his efforts on the southern states of Alabama and Mississippi; two campaigns have avoided conflict until now, favoring attacks on Romney, but observers say a clash has become inevitable.

byline.original: By TRIP GABRIEL and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
byline.contributor: Trip Gabriel reported from Montgomery, and Michael D. Shear from New York. Katharine Q. Seelye contributed reporting from Steubenville, Ohio, and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from Lenexa, Kan.

lead_paragraph: Two important southern primaries are leading Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich to battle each other as they try to show they can unite the party’s conservative base.

headline.seo: As Romney Leads, Santorum and Gingrich Turn on Each Other
headline.main: A Bid to Get Gingrich to Give Up Quest
